Translate to a near‑term reaction function: if pass‑through is ongoing, expect sticky or rising headline/core auto inflation and slower auto demand/margins; if relief or demand is weaker than feared, some cooling could appear in CPI/PCE prints. Catalysts to watch over the next 2–3 weeks include auto price signals from earnings calls, CPI/PCE autos components, and any further tariff policy signals. Bring in a second channel with numbers from credit markets and lending behavior to frame consumer resilience: personal‑loan pricing hinges on broader policy/inflation; fixed vs. variable terms and origination fees drive true borrowing costs, with APR ranges from roughly 8.99%–35.49% and soft pulls advised to avoid score impact (S7M6BJSRT). Finally, resolve conflicts (eg, management comments denying price hikes vs Nikkei pass‑through) by presenting a transparent, triangulated view: cite the Nikkei signal as the near‑term push, the management statements as potential offsets, and Ford/Toyota margin data as sentiment/real‑economy checks; structure the write‑up as Base/Bull/Bear near‑term paths with explicit levels to monitor (auto price trajectory, CPI autos component, and tariff policy updates) and clearly cite only S15934PBQ, S7M6BJSRT, and U1KRCQOYR.
